title: Be Human
description: Sayings and writings of select saints

entries.title: On Karma or Actions
entries.content:encoded:
Karma, or actions, can be both virtuous and sinful. Sinful actions lead to suffering, while virtuous actions lead to happiness. The experience of suffering or happiness in the realms of hell and heaven is a manifestation of the mind's imagination, which is realized in the realm of consciousness (Chidakasha).

As individuals engage in actions, corresponding impressions are imprinted in their minds, influencing their inner emotional states and determining their future circumstances. Those who perform actions possess a unique competence that shapes their future state of existence. The skills and actions a person possesses ultimately dictate their state, status, and place in the grand scheme of nature; this is the law of nature.

Just as actions in the waking state can manifest in the dream state and evoke joy or sorrow for the dreamer, similarly, at the end of life, the soul or surat enters the Chidakasha, the realm of consciousness, and faces either favorable or unfavorable circumstances based on its accumulated actions. These states are referred to as heaven and hell, and there is nothing beyond them.

This realm exists because every living being must have a dwelling place, even the subtlest of subtle entities. As long as virtuous and sinful karma persist, individuals will inevitably journey to heaven and hell, experiencing happiness and suffering as dictated by their actions. This is the natural order. When one's deeds are purified, they earn the right to transcendence and liberation from the bonds of the world.

The consequences of a practitioner's actions are experienced in various ways. Some manifest as physical ailments and mental suffering, while others are encountered within the realm of the mind during the practice. It is inevitable to experience the repercussions of one's actions. The Upanishads assert that whatever good or bad deeds a person performs, they must face the consequences.

In the case of a practitioner, due to their focused mind, they easily bear the consequences, whereas others may have to endure significant hardship. The concentration of the mind generates a special kind of energy that continually burns the imprints of actions. This is how one experiences the outcomes of their actions. If these actions and their consequences are not faced, there will be no way to transcend the spiritual realms.

The effects of a person's actions remain within them, securely stored, and surface when assistance is provided. One who engages in good or bad deeds dreams accordingly. In the unconsciousness of illness, one speaks similarly. Also, at the time of death, these deeds come to the forefront and attract one's attention, compelling them to enter either heaven or hell. The practice serves to cleanse these deeds.

For good health, it is essential to eliminate the impurities from the body. Similarly, for genuine spiritual well-being, it is necessary to eradicate the impurities of actions and impure thoughts through practice. Otherwise, the mirror of the mind's sky will continue to reflect the imprints of actions, keeping them trapped, and naturally, it will remain under the control of mental power, continually awakening them.

In the Radhaswami path, virtuous deeds are those that draw one closer to the feet of the Satpurush Radhaswami (The Supermost Element), while bad deeds create distance from him.

entries.title: The Essence of Yog
entries.content:encoded:
The term "Yog" essentially means coming together, connecting, or merging. It originates from the Sanskrit word "yuj," which translates to "to join." The primary and secondary meanings of Yog are quite similar. It's like finding harmony or agreement, which can also be thought of as a kind of union. When people engage in religious meditation, they focus their minds on something abstract that binds them or links them. This, too, is a form of Yog or Union.

Similar to other situations, Yog also has various stages. These stages represent how strongly you connect with the thing you're trying to unite with. Imagine living in an area that's surrounded by a specific river. You become connected to it in a sense because you're situated in the region where that river flows. The moisture from the river fills the air around you, and you naturally absorb it. This is called "Salok-Yog" in Sanskrit, which means living in the deity's specific zone.

Now, let's say you get closer to the river itself. The connection becomes stronger. The moisture in the air becomes more noticeable, and you're not just influenced by it, but you're intimately in contact with its watery environment. In Sanskrit, this closeness is termed "Samep-Yog" or Union of nearness.

Lastly, consider the situation where you dive into the river. Water surrounds you on all sides - above, below, right, and left. Your body is completely immersed in the water. Although you're still distinct from the water, you appear almost like a part of it, akin to a fish in a pond. In Sanskrit, this is known as "Sarup-Yog," which means having the same form.

In essence, Yog represents different levels of connection or merging, ranging from simply being in the presence of something to becoming an integral part of it. This concept helps us understand the various degrees of closeness and unity in our experiences.

After the previous stages of connection, there's an even deeper level called intimate union. At this point, the person's soul takes on the characteristics of the thing it's connecting with, to the point of becoming indistinguishable from it. This is when true identification occurs. In Sanskrit, this is referred to as "Sayuj-Yog," which can be thought of as Perfect Unification. This stage is the heart of Yog-philosophy, encompassing the essence of the entire concept.

entries.title: On Love & Purity of Mind
entries.description: by Maharishi Shiv Brat Lal Verman
entries.content:encoded:
“…It is crucial to understand that the suffering and entrapment in the world are caused by the mind's fickleness. This fickleness leads to ignorance of reality or truth, trapping us in the physical world. To break free, we must discipline the mind through practice. By gaining control over the mind, we can rise beyond the sky and attain knowledge, liberation, and bliss…

Why should one be led beyond the sky? The reason lies in the fact that the origin of all elements is from the realms of the sky and the cosmos. It is from these elements that the body, senses, mind, and intellect are formed, and worldly objects are acquired which causes attachment and bondage. Therefore, the primary step towards gaining discernment is to purify the mind. Furthermore, seeking true knowledge and wisdom requires transcending these elemental realms. That's why practicing and elevating the mind upwards is essential.”

“Without the presence of true love, the purity of the mind cannot be achieved. As long as the heart remains impure, the influence of one's emotions won't affect others. This principle mirrors the natural law - even a slight flaw in a mirror prevents a clear image. By wholeheartedly embracing the true love of someone, individuals naturally absorb their mental clarity, purity, and impartiality…By filling the mind with love, one can continue to keep it clean and pure. It doesn't demand great effort, just a little perseverance. When the mind is imbued with the colors of love and realization in the presence of the True Guru, it naturally reveals the true essence of the Guru's teachings, and everything falls into place effortlessly…However, not all beings are capable of loving in this manner. That's why they are taught the practice of Shabad Yog (union with the inner sound current) and Satsang, which provide guidance internally and externally. Slowly, the magic of love is instilled, and the seeker is granted the inheritance of the Guru's company, love, saintly knowledge, and spiritual wisdom.”

“They say “Love is blind”, and it is quite so, for, where there is Love, there is no reasoning and no wrangling of words. Love is its own proof. It required no proof for its presence or existence. Love is a pervading-principle. Had it not been present everywhere, the World would not have come into existence. It is Love that creates, it is Love that multiplies, and it is Love that finds room for everybody. We are born, we live, and die, and are absorbed in Love, for God is nothing but Love. Had there been no Love, there would have been no God. Had there been no God. There would have been no Love.

Love and God are the same thing.”

— Maharishi Shiv Brat Lal Verman, Radhaswami Yog

entries.title: सुख (Sukha)
entries.description: A few poems on Sukha by Maharishi Shiv Brat Lal Verman
entries.content:encoded:
All living beings know Dukha (suffering, unhappiness, dissatisfaction) and each living being is searching for Sukha (ease, happiness, satisfaction). In the poems below, Maharishi Shiv points out that the suffering we experience is a kind of cleanse. It forces us to get rid of what is unhelpful or harmful to us. Suffering due to consequences of our ill thoughts and ill actions is only natural. In times of happiness or ease, we forget our true nature (Nij Roop). Dukha or suffering reminds us of the true reality and our true nature. It asks us to turn our face away from all that is changing and impermanent outside and turn within for peace and stability. The supreme purpose of our lives is to know our true Self (Nij Roop). Maharishi says that ease and happiness are a very natural outcome of abiding in one’s true Self (Nij Roop) within.

Now, you may ask yourself:

  • What is my true nature or true Self?

  • Is it my body? or my mind (thoughts)? or my consciousness?

  • Or is my true Self the entity that witnesses all the happenings of consciousness, mind, and body?
